Louisiana lawmakers won’t allow for rape, incest exceptions to abortion ban
Legislation that deals with medical exemptions to the abortion ban may get a hearing next week 



By: Julie O'Donoghue - May 10, 2023 2:26 pm


























  
 A Louisiana House of Representatives committee voted down two proposals to provide exceptions to the state abortion ban in cases of rape and incest. (Otto Kitsinger for States Newsroom)





Louisiana lawmakers scuttled proposals Wednesday to carve out more exceptions to the state’s strict abortion ban this year, in spite of months of complaints from doctors and pregnant women that the law has unintended consequences.
The Louisiana House Committee on the Administration of Criminal Justice voted down two bills that would have allowed more people to legally terminate their pregnancies if they result from rape or incest. But three other pieces of legislation that deal with medical exemptions and penalties for doctors remain in play for lawmakers. 
Rep. Aimee Freeman, D-New Orleans, pushed off until next week a vote on her proposal, House Bill 522, that lessens criminal penalties for doctors who perform illegal abortions. Freeman said in an interview that she hopes she can make adjustments to the legislation that will make it more likely to pass.

Meanwhile, Reps. Candace Newell, D-New Orleans, and Mary DuBuisson, R-Slidell, hope to get their bills that deal with medical exemptions to the abortion ban moved to another committee for consideration.
Newell’s House Bill 598 would clarify that abortion is legal when a person is undergoing treatment for cancer, blood disorders and other medical challenges. DuBuisson’s House Bill 461 also attempts to clear up when a person qualifies for a medical exemption to the abortion ban and lowers the barrier to getting permission for one. 

The criminal justice committee agreed to refer Newell’s legislation to the House Health and Welfare Committee. DuBuisson said she is also trying to get her legislation reassigned to the health committee.

DONATE



	  
The current legislative session presents the first opportunity for lawmakers to change Louisiana’s abortion ban since it went into effect last year. Legislators had not convened a regular lawmaking session since the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last June. 
Advocates of loosening abortion restrictions faced an uphill battle, however. The Legislature is overwhelmingly conservative and opposed to abortion. Criminal justice committee members rejected bills to allow for rape and incest exceptions on 10-5 and 9-5 votes Wednesday, with all Republicans on the committee opposed.

Those votes came after hours of gut-wrenching testimony from rape victims, incest victims and medical professionals on both sides of the issue.
“If you are forcing survivors of rape and incest to carry a pregnancy, you are not supporting victims,” said Katie Hunter-Lowry, a rape survivor who runs Louisiana Survivors for Reform.
“Rape has always been used as an excuse to legalize abortion,” said former Rep. Woody Jenkins, a Baton Rouge Republican testifying against the bills.
One of the sponsors of the legislation to provide rape and incest exceptions, Rep. Delisha Boyd, D-New Orleans, had a personal connection to the issue. Boyd said her mother was 15 years-old when she gave birth to Boyd after being raped by a 28 year-old man. Boyd’s mother, who died before she was 30 years-old, never got over the event, she said.
“My mother did not survive her trauma. It was overwhelming for her and she didn’t have a choice in the 60s,” Boyd said. “I didn’t always understand, but I get it today.”
Rep. Tony Bacala, R-Prairieville, had a different take on Boyd’s story.
Bacala told Boyd that he was more inclined to vote against Boyd’s legislation because he thought it was a blessing that a good person like Boyd was born and her mother wasn’t given the option to terminate her pregnancy.

DONATE



The rape and incest exceptions would do nothing to address another concern with the abortion ban however. Doctors have said the current law is interfering with their efforts to treat people who face complications with pregnancy because physicians and hospitals fear the criminal charges they might now face.
The law allows people to still have abortions if their life is threatened by pregnancy or they are in danger of damaging a “life-sustaining” organ. They can also terminate pregnancies if they are miscarrying or their fetus is diagnosed as being “medically nonviable” by two doctors — meaning their pregnancy is expected to produce a baby that can’t survive outside the womb.
But at least a couple of women have come forward in Louisiana to say they have had difficulty getting care after their pregnancies had failed. Baton Rouge resident Nancy Davis said she had to fly to New York to terminate a pregnancy after being told her fetus would never grow a skull and couldn’t survive after birth. She said she couldn’t find a Louisiana hospital to perform the abortion for her.
Anti-abortion advocates have suggested the statute isn’t the problem. Hospitals, doctors and their attorneys might be interpreting the law much more narrowly than it should, they said.
Some medical professionals have also said its a barrier for rural hospitals and smaller medical clinics to find two doctors who can sign off the paperwork needed for a legal abortion due to medical complications.
Newell and DuBuisson seek to address some of that confusion over medical exceptions through legislation.
Newell wants to list more specific conditions — such as cancer and blood disorders — that would allow for an exception to the abortion ban in the statute. DuBuisson would allow just one doctor — instead of the two required now — to authorize the termination of a pregnancy because of miscarriage or another medical condition.
